instruction: What are the requirements for high-risk AI systems?
response:
High-risk AI systems under the EU AI Act are AI systems listed in Annex III or certified under specific product safety legislation.

Key requirements include:
• Risk management system
• Data governance and data quality
• Technical documentation
• Record-keeping and logging
• Transparency and provision of information to users
• Human oversight
• Accuracy, robustness and cybersecurity

These requirements are detailed in Article 6, Article 16, Article 17 and other relevant articles of Regulation (EU) 2024/1689.

High-risk AI systems under the EU AI Act are AI systems listed in Annex III or certified under specific product safety legislation.

Key requirements include:
• Risk management system
• Data governance and data quality
• Technical documentation
• Record-keeping and logging
• Transparency and provision of information to users
• Human oversight
• Accuracy, robustness and cybersecurity

These requirements are detailed in Article 6, Article 16, Article 17 and other relevant articles of Regulation (EU) 2024/1689.

High-risk AI systems under the EU AI Act are AI systems listed in Annex III or certified under specific product safety legislation.

Key requirements include:
• Risk management system
• Data governance and data quality
• Technical documentation
• Record-keeping and logging
• Transparency and provision of information to users
• Human oversight
• Accuracy, robustness and cybersecurity

These requirements are detailed in Article 6, Article 16, Article 17 and other relevant articles of Regulation (EU) 2024/1689.

instruction: Explain Article 5 of the EU AI Act.
response:
Article 5 of the EU AI Act prohibits AI practices that pose unacceptable risks. These include:

• Subliminal techniques beyond consciousness
• Exploitation of vulnerabilities of specific groups
• Social scoring by public authorities
• Real-time remote biometric identification in public spaces

These practices are considered to violate fundamental rights and are completely banned under the EU AI Act.

• Exploitation of vulnerabilities of specific groups
• Social scoring by public authorities
• Real-time remote biometric identification in public spaces

These practices are considered to violate fundamental rights and are completely banned under the EU AI Act.

• Exploitation of vulnerabilities of specific groups
• Social scoring by public authorities
• Real-time remote biometric identification in public spaces

These practices are considered to violate fundamental rights and are completely banned under the EU AI Act.

• Exploitation of vulnerabilities of specific groups
• Social scoring by public authorities
• Real-time remote biometric identification in public spaces

These practices are considered to violate fundamental rights and are completely banned under the EU AI Act.

instruction: Define 'AI system' according to the EU AI Act.
response: According to the EU AI Act (Regulation EU 2024/1689), 'AI system' is defined as: A machine-based system that is designed to operate with varying levels of autonomy and that may exhibit adaptiveness after deployment, and that, for explicit or implicit objectives, infers, from the input it receives, how to generate outputs such as predictions, content, recommendations, or decisions that can influence physical or virtual environments

instruction: What is a 'high-risk AI system' under the EU AI Act?
response: According to the EU AI Act (Regulation EU 2024/1689), 'high-risk AI system' is defined as: An AI system listed in Annex III or an AI system that is a safety component of a product covered by Union harmonisation legislation

instruction: How does the EU AI Act define 'provider'?
response: According to the EU AI Act (Regulation EU 2024/1689), 'provider' is defined as: A natural or legal person that develops an AI system or a general-purpose AI model or that has an AI system or a general-purpose AI model developed and places it on the market or puts it into service under its own name or trademark

instruction: Explain the term 'deployer' as used in Regulation (EU) 2024/1689.
response: According to the EU AI Act (Regulation EU 2024/1689), 'deployer' is defined as: A natural or legal person that has authority over the use of an AI system, also where the use is carried out in the context of a personal non-professional activity

response: According to the EU AI Act (Regulation EU 2024/1689), 'provider' is defined as: A natural or legal person that develops an AI system or a general-purpose AI model or that has an AI system or a general-purpose AI model developed and places it on the market or puts it into service under its own name or trademark

instruction: Explain the term 'deployer' as used in Regulation (EU) 2024/1689.
response: According to the EU AI Act (Regulation EU 2024/1689), 'deployer' is defined as: A natural or legal person that has authority over the use of an AI system, also where the use is carried out in the context of a personal non-professional activity

instruction: Define 'AI system' according to the EU AI Act.
response: According to the EU AI Act (Regulation EU 2024/1689), 'AI system' is defined as: A machine-based system that is designed to operate with varying levels of autonomy and that may exhibit adaptiveness after deployment, and that, for explicit or implicit objectives, infers, from the input it receives, how to generate outputs such as predictions, content, recommendations, or decisions that can influence physical or virtual environments

response: According to the EU AI Act (Regulation EU 2024/1689), 'provider' is defined as: A natural or legal person that develops an AI system or a general-purpose AI model or that has an AI system or a general-purpose AI model developed and places it on the market or puts it into service under its own name or trademark

instruction: Explain the term 'deployer' as used in Regulation (EU) 2024/1689.
response: According to the EU AI Act (Regulation EU 2024/1689), 'deployer' is defined as: A natural or legal person that has authority over the use of an AI system, also where the use is carried out in the context of a personal non-professional activity

instruction: Define 'AI system' according to the EU AI Act.
response: According to the EU AI Act (Regulation EU 2024/1689), 'AI system' is defined as: A machine-based system that is designed to operate with varying levels of autonomy and that may exhibit adaptiveness after deployment, and that, for explicit or implicit objectives, infers, from the input it receives, how to generate outputs such as predictions, content, recommendations, or decisions that can influence physical or virtual environments

response: According to the EU AI Act (Regulation EU 2024/1689), 'provider' is defined as: A natural or legal person that develops an AI system or a general-purpose AI model or that has an AI system or a general-purpose AI model developed and places it on the market or puts it into service under its own name or trademark

instruction: Explain the term 'deployer' as used in Regulation (EU) 2024/1689.
response: According to the EU AI Act (Regulation EU 2024/1689), 'deployer' is defined as: A natural or legal person that has authority over the use of an AI system, also where the use is carried out in the context of a personal non-professional activity

instruction: Define 'AI system' according to the EU AI Act.
response: According to the EU AI Act (Regulation EU 2024/1689), 'AI system' is defined as: A machine-based system that is designed to operate with varying levels of autonomy and that may exhibit adaptiveness after deployment, and that, for explicit or implicit objectives, infers, from the input it receives, how to generate outputs such as predictions, content, recommendations, or decisions that can influence physical or virtual environments

response: According to the EU AI Act (Regulation EU 2024/1689), 'AI system' is defined as: A machine-based system that is designed to operate with varying levels of autonomy and that may exhibit adaptiveness after deployment, and that, for explicit or implicit objectives, infers, from the input it receives, how to generate outputs such as predictions, content, recommendations, or decisions that can influence physical or virtual environments

instruction: What is a 'high-risk AI system' under the EU AI Act?
response: According to the EU AI Act (Regulation EU 2024/1689), 'high-risk AI system' is defined as: An AI system listed in Annex III or an AI system that is a safety component of a product covered by Union harmonisation legislation

instruction: How does the EU AI Act define 'provider'?
response: According to the EU AI Act (Regulation EU 2024/1689), 'provider' is defined as: A natural or legal person that develops an AI system or a general-purpose AI model or that has an AI system or a general-purpose AI model developed and places it on the market or puts it into service under its own name or trademark

instruction: How should AI providers ensure compliance with the EU AI Act?
response: AI providers must ensure their systems comply with EU AI Act requirements including risk management, data governance, technical documentation, and ongoing monitoring. They must implement quality management systems and conduct conformity assessments for high-risk AI systems.

instruction: What compliance measures must AI deployers implement?
response: AI deployers must use AI systems according to instructions, monitor for risks, ensure human oversight, and report serious incidents. They must also conduct impact assessments for high-risk AI systems in certain contexts.

instruction: What are the compliance obligations for high-risk AI system operators?
response: High-risk AI system operators must implement comprehensive risk management, ensure data quality, maintain technical documentation, provide transparency to users, ensure human oversight, and continuously monitor system performance and accuracy.

instruction: How should AI providers ensure compliance with the EU AI Act?
response: AI providers must ensure their systems comply with EU AI Act requirements including risk management, data governance, technical documentation, and ongoing monitoring. They must implement quality management systems and conduct conformity assessments for high-risk AI systems.

instruction: What compliance measures must AI deployers implement?
response: AI deployers must use AI systems according to instructions, monitor for risks, ensure human oversight, and report serious incidents. They must also conduct impact assessments for high-risk AI systems in certain contexts.

instruction: What are the compliance obligations for high-risk AI system operators?
response: High-risk AI system operators must implement comprehensive risk management, ensure data quality, maintain technical documentation, provide transparency to users, ensure human oversight, and continuously monitor system performance and accuracy.

instruction: How does the EU AI Act regulate general-purpose AI model providers?
response: AI providers must ensure their systems comply with EU AI Act requirements including risk management, data governance, technical documentation, and ongoing monitoring. They must implement quality management systems and conduct conformity assessments for high-risk AI systems.
